metadata.title: Enterprise Value (TEV) Calculator — Multi‑method
metadata.description: Calculate Enterprise Value (Total Enterprise Value, TEV) using multiple industry methods: market approach (from market capitalization and balance-sheet items), EBITDA multiple approach, and sum-of-parts. Includes adjustments, assumptions, and safety notes on data quality and limits.

market_approach.label: Market approach (Market cap + Net debt + other items)
market_approach.description: Calculates Enterprise Value starting from market capitalization and reconciling balance-sheet items and user adjustments.

enterprise_value_calc.expression: market_cap + total_debt + minority_interest + preferred_stock + other_noncontrolling_interest - cash_and_equivalents + other_adjustments
enterprise_value_calc.label: Enterprise Value (market approach)

multiple_approach.label: Multiple approach (EBITDA × EV/EBITDA multiple)
multiple_approach.description: Estimates Enterprise Value by applying an EV/EBITDA multiple to reported or normalized EBITDA, with optional adjustments.

sum_of_parts.label: Sum-of-parts (SOP) approach
sum_of_parts.description: Aggregates independently valued business units and non-operating assets, then applies adjustments.

fields.label: Other noncontrolling items (e.g., lease liabilities, unfunded pensions)
Adjustments (subtractions) — e.g., liabilities not captured above

introduction: Enterprise Value (EV or TEV) represents the total value of a company attributable to all providers of capital: equity holders, debt holders and other claimants. It is commonly used for valuation comparisons, takeover premiums, and as the numerator in valuation multiples.

This calculator supports three common methods: market approach (market capitalization plus net debt and adjustments), the EBITDA multiple approach (EV = EBITDA × multiple), and a sum-of-parts approach. Use the method that best matches your available data and purpose, and record assumptions when presenting results.
methodology: Market approach: start from market capitalization (public companies) and add claim items (total debt, minority interest, preferred stock), subtract cash, and apply one‑time or recurring adjustments. This reflects amount attributable to all capital providers.

Multiple approach: apply an appropriate EV/EBITDA multiple to an EBITDA figure that has been selected and, if needed, normalized for one‑offs. Choose multiples from comparable companies or transaction precedents and document the source and date.
Sum-of-parts: value each operating segment and non‑operating assets independently, aggregate the parts, then include or exclude liabilities consistently with how parts were valued.
how_is_calculated: Market approach formula: EV = market_cap + total_debt + minority_interest + preferred_stock + other_noncontrolling_interest - cash_and_equivalents + (adjustments_positive - adjustments_negative).
Multiple approach formula: EV = EBITDA × (EV/EBITDA multiple) + (adjustments_positive - adjustments_negative).
examples: Example (market approach): Market cap $500m + total debt $120m + minority interest $10m + preferred $0 - cash $30m = $600m (before adjustments).
Example (multiple approach): EBITDA $50m × multiple 8 = $400m. Add/subtract adjustments like non-operating cash or pension deficits to reconcile to final EV.

faqs.question: Should I use reported debt or enterprise value‑adjusted debt?
faqs.answer: Use the debt measure consistent with your valuation approach. Reported total debt is common; for financial transactions you may use net borrowings, off‑balance sheet obligations, lease liabilities or present value of pensions. Document any adjustments and, if material, perform sensitivity checks.

faqs.question: How do I choose an EV/EBITDA multiple?
faqs.answer: Select peers or precedent transactions with similar growth, margin profile, and capital intensity. Ensure the EBITDA basis (reported vs. normalized) matches how multiples were derived. Run sensitivity ranges to show valuation dependence on the multiple.

faqs.question: Are minority interest and preferred stock always added?
faqs.answer: Yes, to reflect claims on enterprise value they are typically added. The objective is to measure value available to all capital providers before isolating equity value.

faqs.question: What are common pitfalls?
faqs.answer: Mixing incompatible bases (using reported EBITDA with transaction multiples that were based on normalized EBITDA), omitting lease liabilities or pension deficits, and failing to document one‑time adjustments. Always reconcile to audited financial statements where possible.

faqs.question: How accurate is this calculator?
faqs.answer: This tool computes EV from inputs using standard formulas. Accuracy depends entirely on the correctness and consistency of your inputs and assumptions. Use outputs for indicative analysis and stress‑test key assumptions; do not rely on a single-point estimate for transaction pricing or regulatory filings.

glossary.definition: Total value of a company to all capital providers: equity holders, debt holders, preferred and minority interests, adjusted for cash and other items.
Share price multiplied by the number of outstanding shares; represents equity market value for public companies.
Total interest‑bearing debt minus cash and cash equivalents; used to approximate debt claim on the company.
Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization; a common cash‑flow proxy for valuation multiples.
A valuation multiple that expresses Enterprise Value as a multiple of EBITDA; used to compare relative valuations across companies or transactions.
